Posts.Content: Madison wrote: I spoke with Vicki G's Mother Patti today.   She called to thank us for the afghan that we sent Vicki.     She asked that I please let you all know how much your love, friendship and support meant to Vicki and her family. I did tell Ms. Patti how much Vicki meant to us and how much she was loved by all on these boards. I will print part of the e-mail I received which does give the information for Vicki's Celebration of Life Service to be held August 15th.   "Dear Dee, It was very nice speaking with you earlier this afternoon.  The afghan that Vicki received was just beautiful and will always be a reminder of the wonderful women of BreastCancer.Org.  Vicki received so much love, support, information and courage from the web site.  No one knows what Vicki went thru any more than all her web sisters who are walking in her shoes, too.  I pray that there will soon be a cure for this insidious disease that is taking our girls from their families.  There will be a Celebration of Vicki's Life on Saturday, August 15, 2009 at 2 p.m. in Evans, GA. The Celebration will be held at the River Ridge Elementary School, where Vicki spent so much time as volunteer, PTO mom and being very involved in her children's education.  Vicki is survived by her husband, Kevin, her children Cameron (13), Morgan (11), Colin (9) and Madison (7), her parents, Val and Patti Reffett, her brothers Mark Reffett and Scott Reffett. " Vicki's Mom asked that I share this link to Vicki's Guest Book: http://www.legacy.com/gb2/default.aspx?bookid=3307254403020&eid=viewgb_80409 Madison Log in to post a reply

You will make the right decision.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2010 01:48PM - edited May 28, 2010 03:05PM by Madison I'm not sure where you read the quote "We're dying down here".   I really don't think they meant it in the sense of "death" as you are implying.   Perhaps they should have used a different phrase.   I understand that tempers are high in our area but I still think individuals are not making any analogy between their phrase and your phrase. I do know that there is a way of life that may be dying, i.e. the shrimp, oyster, and fishing industry. Most of our fishermen are second, third generation so therefore their "way of life" is dying. The Louisiana barrier islands will be damaged, or destroyed which will expose our state to direct winds from hurricanes. This will put New Orleans and our coastal cities/parishes at greater risk of destruction, so yes; some of our coastal communities could also "die" as a result of irreparable damage. Yes, our brown pelicans are being killed and the breeding grounds being destroyed.   I know they don't think there is any comparison between your phrase and their wording. The damage to our people and cost from the oil spill won't be known for years to come. I do feel for all of my neighbors who have lost their livelihood , their beaches, their protection from our barrier islands, etc. Yes, people can move, perhaps change jobs, etc. but at this time they aren't thinking of other options because the disaster is still unfolding.  Thesaurus states dying:   disappearing, failing, fading, vanishing, on its last legs.   I'm sorry if any comment from our area has insulted you.     Again, I really don't think anyone meant the comment as in the sense of "death", nor meant to hurt anyone by their choice of wording.   Sorry................

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 03:59PM Madison wrote: Trina, I just had an MRI and CT of my lumbar spine.   Both of these tests showed "possible metastatic disease" in L2 and L3"  of my lumbar spine.  My ortho was going to biopsy the areas. My onc ordered a PET Scan and there was no metastatic disease in my lumbar spine.  The biopsy was not necessary. I know you are worried.   I was a bit of a basket case myself.  It will be something other than mets.  Hugs, Madison
